The problem is not our feet, the problem is modern shoe companies and Nike who started redesigning our feet to work in unnatural ways back in mid 20th century.
Do some research into barefoot running, indigenous people around the world who grew up with barefeet, and ultra marathon and you’ll find out how AMAZING our feet are!!! No other animal is evolved to run 26.2 miles+ non-stop. We humans are practically “born to run”. Highly recommend the “born to run” book btw

P. S. Most of our knee problems also stem from unnatural walking and running stroke. We are supposed to contact the ground with forefoot or mid-foot stroke, but unfortunately more that 95% of us have developed to stroke with heals because modern shoes make it hard to walk or run on your mid-foot. Now decades of contacting the ground with your heels and sending shockwaves up your skeleton, leads to all sorts of knee, back, pelvic, and etc. problems over decades. My little brother who grew up indoor barefoot is a perfect proof for me that mid/fore-foot strike is perfectly natural and default to humans. You can also look into the feet and lifestyle of African or indigenous children who’ve run around in fields, mud, and dirt without shoes, perfectly naturally their whole life. Also, the whole flat feet issue among many westerners also stems from their lifestyle of wearing shoes indoors, outdoors, and in some cases on their bed🤮 their entire life and their arches get weak and collapse over time because their shoes are constantly providing support for their arches and their feet muscles get weak to preserve the natural springy shape of the arch

Our neck is the shock absorber between our head/brain and the rest of our body. If you are going to keep the head, then the neck is essential. Without our head's shock absorber any serious injuries (like whiplash) that our neck normally takes would instead cause our head and body to become separated at the location where the bones are supposed to be attempting to keep them together. As we all know, when the bones that connect our brain to the rest of our body are damaged, they are no longer able to protect our spinal column. If our spinal column is injured, we are in trouble. If our spinal column is severed, our brain can no longer keep our organs functioning. Thus, if we are going to remove the human neck from our future, perfect specimen, it would be wise to remove our head, too. There are a few things I'd probably add to the list of things for a perfect "human"
-- More adaptive DNA structure; it's pretty easy to damage our DNA and get it to a state that's unusable, but some organisms can take a lot of DNA damage and just repair and keep going.
-- Get rid of the binary sexes; if all individuals had both the "male" and "female" organs, it would allow any two of the species to reproduce, rather than needing a pair of two different types of the same species. Either individual could take the "mother" [baby carrying] role, or both could at the same time.
-- asexual reproduction option -- being able to reproduce a highly intelligent species without need of a partner could allow for better spread of the species, but having both sexual and asexual reproduction would ensure we wouldn't need to worry about all of the species being clones of any one individual
-- Redo the shoulders, back, basically most of the skeleton along with the mods you'd suggested.
-- Move the brain into the torso and create more protection around it.
-- Have the brain actually be a network of brains that have redundant functionality, including both processing and memory storage.
-- Add a secondary cardiovascular system to help deliver blood to the body and prevent single-point failure due to heart related issues; this is a major weakness of the current design.
-- Exoskeletal structuring and a better integration between the muscles and bone would help improve resistance to damage and strength potential.
-- Stronger bones! Current human bone tissue can be pretty flimsy.
-- Extra limbs and/or prehensile tail -- having more hands/graspers to manipulate the world around us would be helpful.
-- More eye upgrades -- having broader spectrum vision into the UV and IR ranges would be helpful
-- more eyes, since you got rid of the neck, and as such our perfect "human" can't see behind or to the sides without turning their body.

-- Teeth that grow out and are replaced like a shark's
-- more efficient digestive system
-- better energy storage

I don't believe there is a way to create the perfect human body because perfect is subjective. While you believe we need ostrich feet and ankles for balance and walking purposes, it would take away lots of things from those who like to climb or other actions that ostriches cannot physically perform. Besides, the only goal here is to make the human body as protective as possible (to make death less likely). Other factors such as happiness are not considered - humans have learned to work with their bodies for millions of various activities, which make them unique from other creatures. We can swim, climb trees, play a drum set, create technology, build large structures, and so much more - other animals are limited to a few actions due to their own physical and mental abilities. Lastly, our physical features balance out our mental abilities. Other animals have other cool physical features such as the ones listed in the video, but we have more elaborate mental abilities; it's definitely an advantage, considering we took over most of the world's land.
Another thing I would like to point out is the choice of the octopus eyes. Those animals live deep under water, and, as mentioned, they are very photosensitive. On land, they would not be optimal for sight because light travels through air better than it does through water. Not only that, but octopus eyes are constantly submerged. With nothing but air surrounding them, they could dry out quickly. Of course, blinking could slow the damage, but inevitably, it would lead to quicker eye damage and early blindness.

Fun bit about bird lungs, because they are so insanely efficient its extremely common for birds to die from toxins in the air where humans even similar sized mammals will be completely fine for considerably longer, to straight up unaffected. So in short, WW1 would have caused human kind's utter extinction if we had bird lungs. Though I'll give you, our tolerance to pollution is dubious since it encourages more pollution.

For the feet, nice, but ostrich feet are digitigrade, vs human plantigrade, meaning the bird-footed "stands" on their muscle power instead of their bones, meaning that human can't travel as far looking for food, and will struggle to carry it back. In modern parlance this means they can't carry as much, can't work on their feet as hard, and will get less work done as a result in any kind of standing job. Also consider warfare for a moment. Plantigrade humans are able to carry more weight father than a theoretical digitgrade human. This means military humans as we know it can march farther with heavier armor/weapons than ostrich-feet humans, meaning they will out maneuver their enemy in forced marching, and have better defense in combat thanks to that heavy armor. Thus their armies will win the wars, and guess what, losers are wiped out of the gene pools in ancient warfare, which was typically genocidal. Remember a KEY part of bloodlines surviving to the modern day is the ability to win wars in the ancient days. There is a reason after all we have Italians today but no Carthaginians, Greeks but no Trojans, Norwegians but almost no Sami.

That said, yes agree that humans COULD use a reduction of bones in the feet, but the overall design of human feet is actually very good despite the weaknesses.

2 dimensional knees good luck remaining standing. There isn't a walking animal alive that has multi-directional knees. See everything I mentioned about being able to carry more weight father to win wars, this applies here too. Also weak-kneed unbalanced people would be terrible farmers, which is all about lots and lots of hard work and heavy carrying. And given you are far more likely to NOT suffer a catastrophic knee injury, and the advantage are so huge, we see why nature selected this design.

Octopus eyes, you literally will not be able to focus finely enough to read. You NEED round pupils for detailed vision. Have fun being illiterate and unable to work on or create anything with fine details. So how about we steal an octopus's retinas.

No neck? Well we wouldn't have made it then either. Without the ability to swing our heads around "on a swivel" we never would have been able to both find prey and evade predators to make it to the agriculture phase. And if somehow no-necks made it that far, they would be obliterated by the necked in warfare since they...well can't really look around without making awkward twists in a battle, thus giving up situational awareness to necked, who would defeat and kill them in combat.

As for the ribs, while Graham might survive car-crashes, he is going to trade off the stability of his rib cage to be a "core" to attach his arm muscles. Consider people can and have had 2x4's shoved though their chest and lived, the trade off for FAR more functional strength and stability is worth the risk. That...and wear a seatbelt.

So, I know this video is a week old but I've got some issues with it:

TL;DR: There's no definition of a "perfect human" that *all* of us can agree on, so let's focus on making a "flawless human" that just fixes our most common and major flaws that even our ancestors 10,000 + years ago had to deal with.

L;R:

Firstly, we shouldn't be talking about the "perfect" human, because to be honest, that's a slippery slope that will lead into an endless amount of features that might not even make us look human anymore. For instance, yes cephalopods don't have blind spots since their eyes evolved better than ours, but mantis shrimps have 16 different types of cones, allowing them to see colors we can't even imagine, so why not add that in while we're at it? Jellyfish are biologically immortal, let's add those features too. Maybe some humans want to have adaptations of certain sea animals to better swim, maybe adaptations for flying... you get the point, it starts becoming a mess, because everyone's definition of "perfect" is unique, and we eventually get into the conversation of talking about the perfect organism, not the perfect human.

So instead let's talk about a "Flawless" human instead, or at least a "nearly flawless" human. This means removing major flaws from our biology, but leaving alone features and parts that do their job exactly as intended with no major drawbacks. I won't look at things that might improve our current day-to-day lives, just things that we could've started with 10,000 years ago when we were still hunter-gatherers and would still aid us today.

From the top,
1) Eyes - yes, we can fix our blind spot as described in the video, and have better lenses to work with much like cephalopods, good job, no need for other improvements.
2) Ears - To my understanding, there's no major flaws with our ears: they hear the range intended just fine, nothing more to say here.
3) Sinuses - This is a missed opportunity that needs fixing. The mucus in our sinuses, and in all other mammals, are designed to drain down the back of our throat into our stomach - but our lower sinuses have to drain **upwards**, a g a i n s t gravity. These lower sinuses either need to shrink, or the shape of our skulls need to change so that our sinuses drain properly and lower the amount of infections that happen.
4) Necks - Unless I'm mistaken, every vertebrate has a neck, be it long or short, and the only thing we might want to consider would be to give it more reinforcement if it's something our ancestors have had problems with as well.
5) Respiratory System - Yep, using bird lungs are a direct upgrade that we could use, no arguments here. However, the s e v e r e issue of humans choking more frequently than even other mammals is something that needs to be addressed. Since we can't necessarily connect our nostrils directly to our lungs, since we still our sinuses to drain excess mucus into the stomach, we could at least do some tampering and move around the tubes to make choking much less of a hazard.
6) Unless there's an animal out there with ribs that improve upon some current flaw with ours that I'm not aware of, we don't need Graham's ribs, ours work as intended very well.
7) Back - Our backs are *barely* designed to hold ourselves upright, and there aren't many other references in the animal kingdom we can use to fix the various back issues we have with it, so the best we could do would be to give it some additional structural integrity to better hold our weight up.
8) Reproductive System - No arguments with the points made in the video, pouches eliminate the period problems, birth problems, and is probably less taxing on giving nutrients to the baby while it's developing, so this works well. Balls being pushed into the body? If it works without killing the sperm, then perfect. Otherwise, we'll have to work with some other measure of protection to keep them safe, maybe like a mini rib-cage fixed to male's hips.
9) Legs - Let's just modify our entire legs to function more like bird/dinosaur legs and keep it simple. They probably wouldn't look exactly the same, but we don't need to worry about Graham's knee or trying to do other modifications, let's just have bird legs.

Again, this isn't necessarily the "perfect human", just the "nearly flawless human".

There's something called evolutionary convergence and that is different species will develop similar phenotypes if they are in the same enviorment and inhabit the same niche. Broadly stating, you could put preadetors on one side of a spectrum and prey on another. Preadetors usually have more pointed forward facing features as opposed to rounded and side facing. Humans are hunters and are social. Our faces express emotions to others in our species so our faces should be forward facing to communicate emotions. It is also valuable for us to conceal our intent because we live complex social groups. Maybe that's why our ears don't move, because our species requires to be us to convey a lot of information with our faces, but there's probably a point of diminishing returns where if you convey too much true information via your face, you could not compete with those in your species. So we don't need everyone to know what we're listening in on at all times.

I'm sorry guys but the human hearing is between 20 Hz - 20,000 Hz as a new born or young child. 
There even are some people who can actually hear below 20 Hz, into what we call "infra bass" (bass below the hearing threshhold)
As we get older we tend to have a roll off of the higher frequencies and it gets wors the older we are or the more we strain our hearing throughout life.
Might be from working construction, working in a kindergarden or going to conserts without proper protection etc.
20 Hz - 15,000 Hz isn't unusual when we reach 50+ and don't have the work mentioned above or simular noisy working conditions.

We start to have a difficulty hearing the directivity of the sound when the frequency goes below 80 Hz. 
This is why THX recommends you to cross your subwoofer at 80 Hz in your home cinema.

Great video otherwise :)
/C - Sweden

everything they said is pure speculation, and theyre overlooking some aspects of evolutionary theory.

there cant ever be a "perfectly evolved" human. evolution never stops lmao.

not to mention "survival of the fittest" doesnt mean "survival of the physically superior"

evolution can take many strategies.

phytoplankton are USELESS little creatures on theirown. they only survive so well because they reproduce so fast.

not to mention, what constitutes "best evolved" fastest? strongest? fastest reproduction? immunity to disease?

not to mention some attributes are mutually exclusive.

a small agile human can do crazy acrobatics, but not be very strong. just as a 450 lb powerlifter could tip a car over. but they can hardly even jump at all.

in truth, evolutionary theory dictates that NO SPECIES THATS STILL ALIVE is any more, or less evolved than any other.

for example, all the things they said may have the trade off of requiring more nutrients, and being more difficult to maintain. or, could take away another function thats more important.

Although a very interesting video, I disagree with the take of changing what we already have to be "the perfectly evolved human", as you might agree by the end.
The whole point of our existence is that we can do a little bit of everything and we can train/adapt to do almost everything - rememebering in a way what our common ancestors used to do. Just a quick look to videos of parkour compilations, ballet dances, acrobatic olympians, and many many more examples that prove how incredibly versatile and divergent we can train ourselves to be.
So yeah, we can have an ostrich leg to run better, but we wouldn't be able to swim that well anymore or probably not bend the ways we can anymore - or climb or feel things with our feet. I'd make us doublejointed as a norm instead of making a knee go in all directions, think of how complex and inefficiently disjointed our muscles woul be to support all those directions. Also it should be very interesting to see how changing our lungs impacts our breathing patterns everything we evolved to do with those breathing techniques we developed.
